p.verse: 1The words of Amos, who was one of the sheep breeders from Tekoa ​– ​what he saw regarding Israel in the days of King Uzziah of Judah and Jeroboam son of Jehoash, king of Israel, two years before the earthquake.
2He said:

poetryblock.poem: The Lord roars from Zion
and makes his voice heard from Jerusalem;
the pastures of the shepherds mourn,
and the summit of Carmel withers.

p.verse: 3The Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: I will not relent from punishing Damascus
for three crimes, even four,
because they threshed Gilead with iron sledges.

poem.verse: 4Therefore, I will send fire against Hazael’s palace,

poetryblock.poem: and it will consume Ben-hadad’s citadels.

poem.verse: 5I will break down the gates of Damascus.

poetryblock.poem: I will cut off the ruler from the Valley of Aven,
and the one who wields the sceptre from Beth-eden.
The people of Aram will be exiled to Kir.
The Lord has spoken.

p.verse: 6The Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: I will not relent from punishing Gaza
for three crimes, even four,
because they exiled a whole community,
handing them over to Edom.

poem.verse: 7Therefore, I will send fire against the walls of Gaza,

poetryblock.poem: and it will consume its citadels.

poem.verse: 8I will cut off the ruler from Ashdod,

poetryblock.poem: and the one who wields the sceptre from Ashkelon.
I will also turn my hand against Ekron,
and the remainder of the Philistines will perish.
The Lord God has spoken.

p.verse: 9The Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: I will not relent from punishing Tyre
for three crimes, even four,
because they handed over
a whole community of exiles to Edom
and broke a treaty of brotherhood.

poem.verse: 10Therefore, I will send fire against the walls of Tyre,

poetryblock.poem: and it will consume its citadels.

p.verse: 11The Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: I will not relent from punishing Edom
for three crimes, even four,
because he pursued his brother with the sword.
He stifled his compassion,
his anger tore at him continually,
and he harboured his rage incessantly.

poem.verse: 12Therefore, I will send fire against Teman,

poetryblock.poem: and it will consume the citadels of Bozrah.

p.verse: 13The Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: I will not relent from punishing the Ammonites
for three crimes, even four,
because they ripped open
the pregnant women of Gilead
in order to enlarge their territory.

poem.verse: 14Therefore, I will set fire to the walls of Rabbah,

poetryblock.poem: and it will consume its citadels.
There will be shouting on the day of battle
and a violent wind on the day of the storm.

poem.verse: 15Their king and his princes

poetryblock.poem: will go into exile together.
The Lord has spoken.

p.verse: 1The Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: I will not relent from punishing Moab
for three crimes, even four,
because he burned the bones
of the king of Edom to lime.

poem.verse: 2Therefore, I will send fire against Moab,

poetryblock.poem: and it will consume the citadels of Kerioth.
Moab will die with a tumult,
with shouting and the sound of the ram’s horn.

poem.verse: 3I will cut off the judge from the land

poetryblock.poem: and kill all its officials with him.
The Lord has spoken.

p.verse: 4The Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: I will not relent from punishing Judah
for three crimes, even four,
because they have rejected the instruction of the Lord
and have not kept his statutes.
The lies that their ancestors followed
have led them astray.

poem.verse: 5Therefore, I will send fire against Judah,

poetryblock.poem: and it will consume the citadels of Jerusalem.

p.verse: 6The Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: I will not relent from punishing Israel
for three crimes, even four,
because they sell a righteous person for silver
and a needy person for a pair of sandals.

poem.verse: 7They trample the heads of the poor

poetryblock.poem: on the dust of the ground
and obstruct the path of the needy.
A man and his father have sexual relations
with the same girl,
profaning my holy name.

poem.verse: 8They stretch out beside every altar

poetryblock.poem: on garments taken as collateral,
and in the house of their God
they drink wine obtained through fines.

poem.verse: 9Yet I destroyed the Amorite as Israel advanced;

poetryblock.poem: his height was like the cedars,
and he was as sturdy as the oaks;
I destroyed his fruit above and his roots beneath.

poem.verse: 10And I brought you from the land of Egypt

poetryblock.poem: and led you forty years in the wilderness
in order to possess the land of the Amorite.

poem.verse: 11I raised up some of your sons as prophets

poetryblock.poem: and some of your young men as Nazirites.
Is this not the case, Israelites?

poem.verse: 12But you made the Nazirites drink wine

poetryblock.poem: and commanded the prophets,
‘Do not prophesy.’

poem.verse: 13Look, I am about to crush you in your place

poetryblock.poem: as a cart crushes when full of grain.

poem.verse: 14Escape will fail the swift,

poetryblock.poem: the strong one will not maintain his strength,
and the warrior will not save his life.

poem.verse: 15The archer will not stand his ground,

poetryblock.poem: the one who is swift of foot
will not save himself,
and the one riding a horse will not save his life.

poem.verse: 16Even the most courageous of the warriors

poetryblock.poem: will flee naked on that day –

p.verse: 1Listen to this message that the Lord has spoken against you, Israelites, against the entire clan that I brought from the land of Egypt:

poem.verse: 2I have known only you

poetryblock.poem: out of all the clans of the earth;
therefore, I will punish you for all your iniquities.

poem.verse: 3Can two walk together

poetryblock.poem: without agreeing to meet?

poem.verse: 4Does a lion roar in the forest

poetryblock.poem: when it has no prey?
Does a young lion growl from its lair
unless it has captured something?

poem.verse: 5Does a bird land in a trap on the ground

poetryblock.poem: if there is no bait for it?
Does a trap spring from the ground
when it has caught nothing?

poem.verse: 6If a ram’s horn is blown in a city,

poetryblock.poem: aren’t people afraid?
If a disaster occurs in a city,
hasn’t the Lord done it?

poem.verse: 7Indeed, the Lord God does nothing

poetryblock.poem: without revealing his counsel
to his servants the prophets.

poem.verse: 8A lion has roared;

poetryblock.poem: who will not fear?
The Lord God has spoken;
who will not prophesy?

poem.verse: 9Proclaim on the citadels in Ashdod

poetryblock.poem: and on the citadels in the land of Egypt:
Assemble on the mountains of Samaria,
and see the great turmoil in the city
and the acts of oppression within it.

poem.verse: 10The people are incapable of doing right –

poetryblock.poem: this is the Lord’s declaration –
those who store up violence and destruction
in their citadels.

p.verse: 11Therefore, the Lord God says:

poetryblock.poem: An enemy will surround the land;
he will destroy your strongholds
and plunder your citadels.

p.verse: 12The Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: As the shepherd snatches two legs
or a piece of an ear
from the lion’s mouth,
so the Israelites who live in Samaria
will be rescued
with only the corner of a bed
or the cushion of a couch.

poem.verse: 13Listen and testify against the house of Jacob –

poetryblock.poem: this is the declaration of the Lord God,
the God of Armies.

poem.verse: 14I will punish the altars of Bethel

poetryblock.poem: on the day I punish Israel for its crimes;
the horns of the altar will be cut off
and fall to the ground.

poem.verse: 15I will demolish the winter house

poetryblock.poem: and the summer house;
the houses inlaid with ivory will be destroyed,
and the great houses will come to an end.

poem.verse: 1Listen to this message, you cows of Bashan

poetryblock.poem: who are on the hill of Samaria,
women who oppress the poor
and crush the needy,
who say to their husbands,
‘Bring us something to drink.’

p.verse: 2The Lord God has sworn by his holiness:

poetryblock.poem: Look, the days are coming
when you will be taken away with hooks,
every last one of you with fish hooks.

poem.verse: 3You will go through breaches in the wall,

poetryblock.poem: each woman straight ahead,
and you will be driven along towards Harmon.
This is the Lord’s declaration.

poem.verse: 4Come to Bethel and rebel;

poetryblock.poem: rebel even more at Gilgal!
Bring your sacrifices every morning,
your tenths every three days.

poem.verse: 5Offer leavened bread as a thanksgiving sacrifice,

poetryblock.poem: and loudly proclaim your freewill offerings,
for that is what you Israelites love to do!

chapter.p: This is the declaration of the Lord God.

poem.verse: 6I gave you absolutely nothing to eat in all your cities,

poetryblock.poem: a shortage of food in all your communities,
yet you did not return to me.
This is the Lord’s declaration.

poem.verse: 7I also withheld the rain from you

poetryblock.poem: while there were still three months until harvest.
I sent rain on one city
but no rain on another.
One field received rain
while a field with no rain withered.

poem.verse: 8Two or three cities staggered

poetryblock.poem: to another city to drink water
but were not satisfied,
yet you did not return to me.
This is the Lord’s declaration.

poem.verse: 9I struck you with blight and mildew;

poetryblock.poem: the locust devoured
your many gardens and vineyards,
your fig trees and olive trees,
yet you did not return to me.
This is the Lord’s declaration.

poem.verse: 10I sent plagues like those of Egypt;

poetryblock.poem: I killed your young men with the sword,
along with your captured horses.
I caused the stench of your camp
to fill your nostrils,
yet you did not return to me.
This is the Lord’s declaration.

poem.verse: 11I overthrew some of you

poetryblock.poem: as I overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah,
and you were like a burning stick
snatched from a fire,
yet you did not return to me –
This is the Lord’s declaration.

poem.verse: 12Therefore, Israel, that is what I will do to you,

poetryblock.poem: and since I will do that to you,
Israel, prepare to meet your God!

poem.verse: 13He is here:

poetryblock.poem: the one who forms the mountains,
creates the wind,
and reveals his thoughts to man,
the one who makes the dawn out of darkness
and strides on the heights of the earth.
The Lord, the God of Armies, is his name.

p.verse: 1Listen to this message that I am singing for you, a lament, house of Israel:

poem.verse: 2She has fallen;

poetryblock.poem: Virgin Israel will never rise again.
She lies abandoned on her land
with no one to raise her up.

p.verse: 3For the Lord God says:

poetryblock.poem: The city that marches out a thousand strong
will have only a hundred left,
and the one that marches out a hundred strong
will have only ten left in the house of Israel.

p.verse: 4For the Lord says to the house of Israel:

poetryblock.poem: Seek me and live!

poem.verse: 5Do not seek Bethel

poetryblock.poem: or go to Gilgal
or journey to Beer-sheba,
for Gilgal will certainly go into exile,
and Bethel will come to nothing.

poem.verse: 6Seek the Lord and live,

poetryblock.poem: or he will spread like fire
throughout the house of Joseph;
it will consume everything
with no one at Bethel to extinguish it.

poem.verse: 7Those who turn justice into wormwood

poetryblock.poem: also throw righteousness to the ground.

poem.verse: 8The one who made the Pleiades and Orion,

poetryblock.poem: who turns darkness into dawn
and darkens day into night,
who summons the water of the sea
and pours it out over the surface of the earth –
the Lord is his name.

poem.verse: 9He brings destruction on the strong,

poetryblock.poem: and it falls on the fortress.

poem.verse: 10They hate the one who convicts the guilty

poetryblock.poem: at the city gate,
and they despise the one who speaks with integrity.

poem.verse: 11Therefore, because you trample on the poor

poetryblock.poem: and exact a grain tax from him,
you will never live in the houses of cut stone
you have built;
you will never drink the wine
from the lush vineyards
you have planted.

poem.verse: 12For I know that your crimes are many

poetryblock.poem: and your sins innumerable.
They oppress the righteous, take a bribe,
and deprive the poor of justice at the city gates.

poem.verse: 13Therefore, those who have insight will keep silent

poetryblock.poem: at such a time,
for the days are evil.

poem.verse: 14Pursue good and not evil

poetryblock.poem: so that you may live,
and the Lord, the God of Armies,
will be with you
as you have claimed.

poem.verse: 15Hate evil and love good;

poetryblock.poem: establish justice at the city gate.
Perhaps the Lord, the God of Armies, will be gracious
to the remnant of Joseph.

p.verse: 16Therefore the Lord, the God of Armies, the Lord, says:

poetryblock.poem: There will be wailing in all the public squares;
they will cry out in anguish in all the streets.
The farmer will be called on to mourn,
and professional mourners to wail.

poem.verse: 17There will be wailing in all the vineyards,

poetryblock.poem: for I will pass among you.
The Lord has spoken.

poem.verse: 18Woe to you who long for the day of the Lord!

poetryblock.poem: What will the day of the Lord be for you?
It will be darkness and not light.

poem.verse: 19It will be like a man who flees from a lion

poetryblock.poem: only to have a bear confront him.
He goes home and rests his hand against the wall
only to have a snake bite him.

poem.verse: 20Won’t the day of the Lord

poetryblock.poem: be darkness rather than light,
even gloom without any brightness in it?

poem.verse: 21I hate, I despise, your feasts!

poetryblock.poem: I can’t stand the stench
of your solemn assemblies.

poem.verse: 22Even if you offer me

poetryblock.poem: your burnt offerings and grain offerings,
I will not accept them;
I will have no regard
for your fellowship offerings of fattened cattle.

poem.verse: 23Take away from me the noise of your songs!

poetryblock.poem: I will not listen to the music of your harps.

poem.verse: 24But let justice flow like water,

poetryblock.poem: and righteousness like an unfailing stream.

p.verse: 25‘House of Israel, was it sacrifices and grain offerings that you presented to me during the forty years in the wilderness?
26But you have taken up Sakkuth your king and Kaiwan your star god, images you have made for yourselves.
27So I will send you into exile beyond Damascus.’ The Lord, the God of Armies, is his name. He has spoken.

poem.verse: 1Woe to those who are at ease in Zion

poetryblock.poem: and to those who feel secure on the hill of Samaria –
the notable people in this first of the nations,
those the house of Israel comes to.

poem.verse: 2Cross over to Calneh and see;

poetryblock.poem: go from there to great Hamath;
then go down to Gath of the Philistines.
Are you better than these kingdoms?
Is their territory larger than yours?

poem.verse: 3You dismiss any thought of the evil day

poetryblock.poem: and bring in a reign of violence.

poem.verse: 4They lie on beds inlaid with ivory,

poetryblock.poem: sprawled out on their couches,
and dine on lambs from the flock
and calves from the stall.

poem.verse: 5They improvise songs to the sound of the harp

poetryblock.poem: and invent their own musical instruments like David.

poem.verse: 6They drink wine by the bowlful

poetryblock.poem: and anoint themselves with the finest oils
but do not grieve over the ruin of Joseph.

poem.verse: 7Therefore, they will now go into exile

poetryblock.poem: as the first of the captives,
and the feasting of those who sprawl out
will come to an end.

p.verse: 8The Lord God has sworn by himself ​– ​this is the declaration of the Lord, the God of Armies:

poetryblock.poem: I loathe Jacob’s pride
and hate his citadels,
so I will hand over the city and everything in it.

p.verse: 9And if there are ten men left in one house, they will die.
10A close relative and burner will remove his corpse from the house. He will call to someone in the inner recesses of the house, ‘Any more with you? ’

chapter.p: Then he will say, ‘Silence, because the Lord’s name must not be invoked.’

p.verse: 11For the Lord commands:

poetryblock.poem: The large house will be smashed to pieces,
and the small house to rubble.

poem.verse: 12Do horses gallop on the cliffs?

poetryblock.poem: Does anyone plough there with oxen?
Yet you have turned justice into poison
and the fruit of righteousness into wormwood –

poem.verse: 13you who rejoice over Lo-debar

poetryblock.poem: and say, ‘Didn’t we capture Karnaim
for ourselves by our own strength? ’

poem.verse: 14But look, I am raising up a nation

poetryblock.poem: against you, house of Israel –
this is the declaration of the Lord,
the God of Armies –
and they will oppress you
from the entrance of Hamath
to the Brook of the Arabah.

p.verse: 1The Lord God showed me this: He was forming a swarm of locusts at the time the spring crop first began to sprout ​– ​after the cutting of the king’s hay.
2When the locusts finished eating the vegetation of the land, I said, ‘Lord God, please forgive! How will Jacob survive, since he is so small? ’
3The Lord relented concerning this. ‘It will not happen,’ he said.
4The Lord God showed me this: The Lord God was calling for a judgement by fire. It consumed the great deep and devoured the land.
5Then I said, ‘Lord God, please stop! How will Jacob survive, since he is so small? ’
6The Lord relented concerning this. ‘This will not happen either,’ said the Lord God.
7He showed me this: The Lord was standing there by a vertical wall with a plumb line in his hand.
8The Lord asked me, ‘What do you see, Amos? ’

chapter.p: Then the Lord said, ‘I am setting a plumb line among my people Israel; I will no longer spare them:

poem.verse: 9Isaac’s high places will be deserted,

poetryblock.poem: and Israel’s sanctuaries will be in ruins;
I will rise up against the house of Jeroboam
with a sword.’

p.verse: 10Amaziah the priest of Bethel sent word to King Jeroboam of Israel, saying, ‘Amos has conspired against you right here in the house of Israel. The land cannot endure all his words,
11for Amos has said this: “Jeroboam will die by the sword, and Israel will certainly go into exile from its homeland.” ’
12Then Amaziah said to Amos, ‘Go away, you seer! Flee to the land of Judah. Earn your living and give your prophecies there,
13but don’t ever prophesy at Bethel again, for it is the king’s sanctuary and a royal temple.’
14So Amos answered Amaziah, ‘I was not a prophet or the son of a prophet; rather, I was a herdsman, and I took care of sycamore figs.
15But the Lord took me from following the flock and said to me, “Go, prophesy to my people Israel.” ’
16Now hear the word of the Lord. You say:

poetryblock.poem: Do not prophesy against Israel;
do not preach against the house of Isaac.

p.verse: 17Therefore, this is what the Lord says:

poetryblock.poem: Your wife will be a prostitute in the city,
your sons and daughters will fall by the sword,
and your land will be divided up
with a measuring line.
You yourself will die on pagan soil,
and Israel will certainly go into exile
from its homeland.

chapter.head1: Fourth Vision: A Basket of Summer Fruit

p.verse: 1The Lord God showed me this: a basket of summer fruit.
2He asked me, ‘What do you see, Amos? ’

chapter.p: I replied, ‘A basket of summer fruit.’

The Lord said to me, ‘The end has come for my people Israel; I will no longer spare them. 3In that day the temple songs will become wailing’ ​– ​this is the Lord God’s declaration. ‘Many dead bodies, thrown everywhere! Silence! ’

poem.verse: 4Hear this, you who trample on the needy

poetryblock.poem: and do away with the poor of the land,

poem.verse: 5asking, ‘When will the New Moon be over

poetryblock.poem: so that we may sell grain,
and the Sabbath,
so that we may market wheat?
We can reduce the measure
while increasing the price
and cheat with dishonest scales.

poem.verse: 6We can buy the poor with silver

poetryblock.poem: and the needy for a pair of sandals
and even sell the chaff! ’

p.verse: 7The Lord has sworn by the Pride of Jacob:

poetryblock.poem: I will never forget all their deeds.

poem.verse: 8Because of this, won’t the land quake

poetryblock.poem: and all who dwell in it mourn?
All of it will rise like the Nile;
it will surge and then subside
like the Nile in Egypt.

poem.verse: 9And in that day –

poetryblock.poem: this is the declaration of the Lord God –
I will make the sun go down at noon;
I will darken the land in the daytime.

poem.verse: 10I will turn your feasts into mourning

poetryblock.poem: and all your songs into lamentation;
I will cause everyone to wear sackcloth
and every head to be shaved.
I will make that grief
like mourning for an only son
and its outcome like a bitter day.

poem.verse: 11Look, the days are coming –

poetryblock.poem: this is the declaration of the Lord God –
when I will send a famine through the land:
not a famine of bread or a thirst for water,
but of hearing the words of the Lord.

poem.verse: 12People will stagger from sea to sea

poetryblock.poem: and roam from north to east
seeking the word of the Lord,
but they will not find it.

poem.verse: 13In that day the beautiful young women,

poetryblock.poem: the young men also, will faint from thirst.

poem.verse: 14Those who swear by the guilt of Samaria

poetryblock.poem: and say, ‘As your god lives, Dan,’
or, ‘As the way of Beer-sheba lives’ –
they will fall, never to rise again.

chapter.head1: Fifth Vision: The Lord beside the Altar

p.verse: 1I saw the Lord standing beside the altar, and he said:

poetryblock.poem: Strike the capitals of the pillars
so that the thresholds shake;
knock them down on the heads of all the people.
Then I will kill the rest of them with the sword.
None of those who flee will get away;
none of the fugitives will escape.

poem.verse: 2If they dig down to Sheol,

poetryblock.poem: from there my hand will take them;
if they climb up to heaven,
from there I will bring them down.

poem.verse: 3If they hide

poetryblock.poem: on the top of Carmel,
from there I will track them down
and seize them;
if they conceal themselves
from my sight on the sea floor,
from there I will command
the sea serpent to bite them.

poem.verse: 4And if they are driven

poetryblock.poem: by their enemies into captivity,
from there I will command
the sword to kill them.
I will keep my eye on them
for harm and not for good.

poem.verse: 5The Lord, the God of Armies –

poetryblock.poem: he touches the earth;
it melts, and all who dwell in it mourn;
all of it rises like the Nile
and subsides like the Nile of Egypt.

poem.verse: 6He builds his upper chambers

poetryblock.poem: in the heavens
and lays the foundation of his vault
on the earth.
He summons the water of the sea
and pours it out over the surface of the earth.
The Lord is his name.

poem.verse: 7Israelites, are you not like the Cushites to me?

poetryblock.poem: This is the Lord’s declaration.
Didn’t I bring Israel from the land of Egypt,
the Philistines from Caphtor,
and the Arameans from Kir?

poem.verse: 8Look, the eyes of the Lord God

poetryblock.poem: are on the sinful kingdom,
and I will obliterate it
from the face of the earth.
However, I will not totally destroy
the house of Jacob –
this is the Lord’s declaration –

poem.verse: 9for I am about to give the command,

poetryblock.poem: and I will shake the house of Israel
among all the nations,
as one shakes a sieve,
but not a pebble will fall to the ground.

poem.verse: 10All the sinners among my people

poetryblock.poem: who say, ‘Disaster will never overtake
or confront us,’
will die by the sword.

poem.verse: 11In that day

poetryblock.poem: I will restore the fallen shelter of David:
I will repair its gaps,
restore its ruins,
and rebuild it as in the days of old,

poem.verse: 12so that they may possess

poetryblock.poem: the remnant of Edom
and all the nations
that bear my name –
this is the declaration of the Lord; he will do this.

poem.verse: 13Look, the days are coming –

poetryblock.poem: this is the Lord’s declaration –
when the ploughman will overtake the reaper,
and the one who treads grapes
the sower of seed.
The mountains will drip with sweet wine,
and all the hills will flow with it.

poem.verse: 14I will restore the fortunes of my people Israel.

poetryblock.poem: They will rebuild and occupy ruined cities,
plant vineyards and drink their wine,
make gardens and eat their produce.

poem.verse: 15I will plant them on their land,

poetryblock.poem: and they will never again be uprooted
from the land I have given them.
The Lord your God has spoken.
